column1: <META NAME="description" CONTENT="Gazetteer for Scotland: Definitive description of Grantown on Spey (Highland)">

<TD ALIGN="center" WIDTH="100" ROWSPAN="2" BGCOLOR="#ffcc33" HEIGHT="350" VALIGN="top"><TABLE CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="3" BGCOLOR="#ffcc33">
©1995-2007 Gazetteer for Scotland
Grantown on Spey is an inland example of a planned 18th Century village. Started in 1766 by Sir James Grant
column2:
it was created as the focal point for new industries in the area and grew steadly so that by 1841 it had over 1000 inhabitants. However it did not develop as the planned manufacturing centre but rather as a service centre for the surrounding area and with the arrival of the railway in 1863 its popularity grew as a holiday centre.

The Victorian fashion for sports led to the development of tennis courts
column3: bowling greens and a golf course which exist to this day
column4: although now it is equally popular as a holiday centre for skiers
column5:
hill-walkers and those fishermen wishing to salmon fish the River Spey.

The closure of the railway in 1965 has led to the conversion of many of the long stay summer holiday homes into hotels and boarding houses. This
column6: as well as the development of the Cairngorms for skiing
column7: has led to the extension of the holiday season.
